org.easylibs.options

Class Args

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.easylibs.options.Args

  • public abstract class Args
extends java.lang.Object

    Main command line argument parser interface. Args parses command line according to the rules defined by Options which must be supplied to this parser.

    The Args and Args interfaces provides several static factory methods for creating a command line argument parser. There are two types which create a parser and either throw any parsing errors, see of(java.lang.String[], java.lang.Class<?>) or send the errors to user defined or default error handler which consumes the errors, see ofOptional(java.lang.String[], java.lang.Class<?>). In the second case, the parser is returned as a java Optional which the error is handled else where.

    The Options library design separates the option definition from command line parsing into two distinct and separate steps. The Options.Builder is first used to define the option set to be used with the parser. The Args parser then uses the options to parse the command line and store the command line arguments in the Options given.

    Example 1

    The example defines two options a -a and a --file-names[=filename[,...]]. The first option is a simple boolean option and the other a list of files names. An initial list object container will be created to hold the list of file names. 

     final Options options = new Options.Builder()
        .named("a")
        .named("file-names", List.class)
        .build();
 
 try {
        final Args args = Args.of(argv, options);
        args.forEach(System.out::println);
 } catch (ArgException e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
 }

    Example 2

    The 2nd example also defines two options but does not throw any exception. 

     final Options options = new Options.Builder()
        .named("a")
        .named("file-names", List.class)
        .build();
 
 final Optional<Args> optionalArgs = Args.ofOptional(argv, options);
 optionalArgs.ifPresent(args -> args.forEach(System.out::println));

    Implementation Notes: initial release comes with a single implementation of the POSIX/gnu command line argument standard defined in corresponding unix manuals. In the future other parser implementations maybe provided.

    See Also:
    Args, Options, Options.Builder, TypeRegistry

      • of

        public static Args of(java.lang.String[] args,
                      Options options)
               throws UnrecognizedArgException,
                      InvalidArgException

        Create new instance of the default command line argument parser. The defaul is a POSIX parser see PosixGetopt. The parser will use the provided options.

        Parameters:
        args - the command line args to parse
        options - the options to use for parsing and state storing
        Throws:
        UnrecognizedArgException - (checked) thrown by the parser if the command line args contain an option looking arg but no option has been defined
        InvalidArgException - (checked) thrown by the parser if unable to process an options argument. The exception means that option was matched and found, but its argument can not be processed or is missing

      • of

        public static Args of(java.lang.String[] args,
                      java.util.Properties properties)
               throws UnrecognizedArgException,
                      InvalidArgException
        Throws:

        InvalidArgException

      • ofOptional

        public static java.util.Optional<Args> ofOptional(java.lang.String[] args,
                                                  Option<?>... options)

      • ofOptional

        public static java.util.Optional<Args> ofOptional(java.lang.String[] args,
                                                  Options options)

        Create new instance of the default command line argument parser and dispatches instead of throws parser argument exceptions. The defaul is a POSIX parser see PosixGetopt. The parser will use the provided options.

        Any parser errors, the checked exceptions, are dispatched using the global default error handler, setDefaultErrorHandler(java.util.function.Consumer<org.easylibs.options.ArgException>) instead of being thrown. If any error did occur, an empty optional is returned instead of the arg parser. The error handler has access to the arg parser which dispatched the error using ArgException.getArgs() method.

        Parameters:
        args - the command line args to parse
        options - the options to use for parsing and state storing
        Returns:
        the parser is returned if no error was encountered, otherwise any empty Optional.empty() is returned and the error handler is notified
        Throws:
        DuplicateOptionException - (unchecked) thrown if duplicate option is passed within the options array, options are equal if their option names are equal Option.getName()
        TypeMapperNotFoundException - (unchecked) every option provided must have a string to value type mapper registered with the TypeRegistry

      • ofOptional

        public static java.util.Optional<Args> ofOptional(java.lang.String[] args,
                                                  java.util.Properties properties)

      • printError

        public static void printError(ArgException e)
        Prints the error for a parser exception. This is also the default error handler see setDefaultErrorHandler(java.util.function.Consumer<org.easylibs.options.ArgException>).
        Parameters:
        e - exception to for format and print to System.err;

      • setDefaultErrorHandler

        public static void setDefaultErrorHandler(java.util.function.Consumer<ArgException> errorHandler)

      • forEach

        public void forEach(java.util.function.Consumer<Option<?>> action)
        All matched options to be consumed by the provided action.

        Example

         args.forEach(option -> System.out.println(option.toString());
        Or using method references to simplify: 
         args.forEach(System.out::println);
        Parameters:
        action - the action which will consume all matched options

      • getArgs

        public abstract java.lang.String[] getArgs()
        Gets the original argument array. Note, that some parser may rearrange the array, such as when unmatched arguments are moved to the end of the array as is also the behavior of the unix getopt call.
        Returns:
        the args

      • getMatchedArgs

        public abstract java.util.List<java.lang.String> getMatchedArgs()
        Gets the list of all matched arguments on the command line
        Returns:
        the matched args

      • getMatchedOptions

        public java.util.List<Option<?>> getMatchedOptions()
        Gets all of the matched options. Only options which were found on the command line, see Option.isMatched(), by the parser are returned.
        Returns:
        the matched options

      • getOptions

        public abstract Options getOptions()
        Gets the options manager currently registered with this parser.
        Returns:
        the options

      • getUnmatchedArgs

        public abstract java.util.List<java.lang.String> getUnmatchedArgs()
        Gets all the unmatched args. Any command line argument that was not an option and also was not matched as an argument to an option, will be returned here. Posix parser stops parsing after a double dash '--' command line argument is encountered, so any arguments after the double dash, including itself, are returned as unmatched.
        Returns:
        the unmatched args

      • getUnmatchedOptions

        public java.util.List<Option<?>> getUnmatchedOptions()
        Gets all of the unmatched options. All remaining options which were NOT found on the command line, see Option.isUnmatched(), by the parser are returned.
        Returns:
        the unmatched options

      • stream

        public java.util.stream.Stream<? extends Option<?>> stream()
        A stream of all the options currently defined by the registered options manager.
        Returns:
        the stream>
